<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_merchandise">Media and merchandise</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Alice_in_Wonderland_(1951_film)&action=edit&section=11" title="Edit section: Media and merchandise">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Stage_version">Stage version</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Alice_in_Wonderland_(1951_film)&action=edit&section=12" title="Edit section: Stage version">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P><I>Alice in Wonderland</I> has been condensed into a one act stage version entitled, <I>Alice in Wonderland, Jr.</I>. The stage version is solely meant for middle and high school productions and includes the majority of the film's songs and others including <I><A href="/wiki/Song_of_the_South" title="Song of the South">Song of the South</A></I><SPAN class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</SPAN>s "<A href="/wiki/Zip-a-Dee-Doo-Dah" title="Zip-a-Dee-Doo-Dah">Zip-a-Dee-Doo-Dah</A>", two new reprises of "I'm Late!", and three new numbers entitled "Ocean of Tears", "Simon Says", and "Who Are You?" respectively. This 60–80 minute version is licensed by <A href="/wiki/Music_Theatre_International" title="Music Theatre International">Music Theatre International</A> in the Broadway, Jr. Collection along with other Disney Theatrical shows such as <I><A href="/wiki/Aladdin,_Jr." class="mw-redirect" title="Aladdin, Jr.">Disney's Aladdin, Jr.</A></I>, <I><A href="/wiki/Mulan_Jr." title="Mulan Jr.">Disney's Mulan, Jr.</A></I>, <I><A href="/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_(musical)" title="Beauty and the Beast (musical)">Beauty and the Beast</A></I>, Disney's <I><A href="/wiki/High_School_Musical" title="High School Musical">High School Musical</A>: On Stage!</I>, <A href="/wiki/Elton_John" title="Elton John">Elton John</A> and <A href="/wiki/Tim_Rice" title="Tim Rice">Tim Rice</A>'s <I><A href="/wiki/Aida_(musical)" title="Aida (musical)">Aida</A></I>, and many more.<SUP id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-23">[23]</A></SUP></P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="References_in_other_Disney_films">References in other Disney films</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Alice_in_Wonderland_(1951_film)&action=edit&section=13" title="Edit section: References in other Disney films">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<UL>
<LI>In <I><A href="/wiki/Donald_in_Mathmagic_Land" title="Donald in Mathmagic Land">Donald in Mathmagic Land</A></I>, <A href="/wiki/Donald_Duck" title="Donald Duck">Donald Duck</A> wears Alice's dress and has her hairstyle but brown not blond. A larger pencil bird is in the film as well.</LI>
<LI>Bill the Lizard appears as one of Professor Ratigan's henchmen in <I><A href="/wiki/The_Great_Mouse_Detective" title="The Great Mouse Detective">The Great Mouse Detective</A></I>.</LI>
<LI>Alice and several other characters from the film were featured as guests in <I><A href="/wiki/House_of_Mouse" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Mouse">House of Mouse</A></I>, and the Queen of Hearts was one of the villains featured in <I><A href="/wiki/Mickey%27s_House_of_Villains" title="Mickey's House of Villains">Mickey's House of Villains</A></I>. The Mad Hatter was also featured in <I><A href="/wiki/Mickey%27s_Magical_Christmas:_Snowed_in_at_the_House_of_Mouse" title="Mickey's Magical Christmas: Snowed in at the House of Mouse">Mickey's Magical Christmas: Snowed in at the House of Mouse</A></I>.</LI>
<LI>The Mad Hatter and the March Hare were also featured in several episodes of <I><A href="/wiki/Bonkers_(cartoon)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bonkers (cartoon)">Bonkers</A></I>.</LI>
<LI>Bill the Lizard, Tweedledum, Cheshire Cat and the doorknob also appear in the 1988 <A href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures" title="Walt Disney Pictures">Disney</A> film <I><A href="/wiki/Who_Framed_Roger_Rabbit" title="Who Framed Roger Rabbit">Who Framed Roger Rabbit</A></I>.</LI>
<LI>In the opening of <I><A href="/wiki/Aladdin_(1992_Disney_film)" title="Aladdin (1992 Disney film)">Aladdin</A></I>, the peddler tries to sell a hookah much like the one the Caterpillar used.</LI>
<LI>In <I><A href="/wiki/Aladdin_and_the_King_of_Thieves" title="Aladdin and the King of Thieves">Aladdin and the King of Thieves</A></I>, the Genie turns into the White Rabbit.</LI>
<LI>On <I><A href="/wiki/Darkwing_Duck" title="Darkwing Duck">Darkwing Duck</A></I>, there is a villain called Tuskernini, a character that somewhat resembles the walrus.</LI>
<LI>Weebo shows clips of the film on her screen in <I><A href="/wiki/Flubber_(film)" title="Flubber (film)">Flubber</A></I>.</LI>
<LI>An episode of <I><A href="/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_Clubhouse" title="Mickey Mouse Clubhouse">Mickey Mouse Clubhouse</A></I>, entitled "Mickey's Adventures in Wonderland", is based on the film.</LI>
<LI>During the song <A href="/wiki/When_You_Wish_upon_a_Star" class="mw-redirect" title="When You Wish upon a Star">When You Wish upon a Star</A> in Disney's <A href="/wiki/Pinocchio_(1940_film)" title="Pinocchio (1940 film)">Pinocchio</A>, the book for Alice in Wonderland can be seen on the bookshelf where <A href="/wiki/Jiminy_Cricket" title="Jiminy Cricket">Jiminy Cricket</A> is singing from. This reference can be considered indirect as the film was released 11 years prior to Alice in Wonderland.</LI>
</UL>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Theme_parks">Theme parks</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Alice_in_Wonderland_(1951_film)&action=edit&section=14" title="Edit section: Theme parks">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<DIV class="thumb tright">
<DIV class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><A href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_Alice_2012-06-30.jpg" class="image"><IMG alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Disneyland_Alice_2012-06-30.jpg/250px-Disneyland_Alice_2012-06-30.jpg" width="250" height="188" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Disneyland_Alice_2012-06-30.jpg/375px-Disneyland_Alice_2012-06-30.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Disneyland_Alice_2012-06-30.jpg/500px-Disneyland_Alice_2012-06-30.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456" /></A>
<DIV class="thumbcaption">
<DIV class="magnify"><A href="/wiki/File:Disneyland_Alice_2012-06-30.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></A></DIV>
Alice at <A href="/wiki/Disneyland" title="Disneyland">Disneyland</A>, 2012.</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>Costumed versions of Alice, The Mad Hatter, The White Rabbit, The Queen of Hearts, Tweedledum, and Tweedledee make regular appearances at the Disney theme parks and resorts, and other characters from the film (including the Walrus and the March Hare) have featured in the theme parks. More famously, all five Disneyland-style theme parks feature <A href="/wiki/Mad_Tea_Party" title="Mad Tea Party">Mad Tea Party</A>, a <A href="/wiki/Teacups" title="Teacups">teacups</A> ride based on Disney's adaptation of <I>Alice in Wonderland</I>.</P>
<P><I>Alice in Wonderland</I> is also frequently featured in many parades and shows in the Disney Theme Parks, including <A href="/wiki/Main_Street_Electrical_Parade" title="Main Street Electrical Parade">The Main Street Electrical Parade</A>, <A href="/wiki/SpectroMagic" title="SpectroMagic">SpectroMagic</A>, <I><A href="/wiki/Fantasmic!" title="Fantasmic!">Fantasmic!</A></I>, <A href="/wiki/Main_Street_Electrical_Parade" title="Main Street Electrical Parade">Dreamlights</A>, The Move It! Shake It! Celebrate It! Street Party and <A href="/wiki/Walt_Disney%27s_Parade_of_Dreams" title="Walt Disney's Parade of Dreams">Walt Disney's Parade of Dreams</A>. <A href="/wiki/Disneyland" title="Disneyland">Disneyland</A> contains a <A href="/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_(Disneyland_attraction)" title="Alice in Wonderland (Disneyland attraction)">dark ride based on the film</A> in addition to the teacups,<SUP id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-24">[24]</A></SUP> and <A href="/wiki/Disneyland_Paris" title="Disneyland Paris">Disneyland Paris</A> also contains a hedge maze called <A href="/wiki/Alice%27s_Curious_Labyrinth" title="Alice's Curious Labyrinth">Alice's Curious Labyrinth</A>, which takes its inspiration from the film.<SUP id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-25">[25]</A></SUP> The now-defunct <A href="/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_Revue" title="Mickey Mouse Revue">Mickey Mouse Revue</A>, shown at <A href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_World" title="Walt Disney World">Walt Disney World</A> and later at <A href="/wiki/Tokyo_Disneyland" title="Tokyo Disneyland">Tokyo Disneyland</A>, contained characters and scenes from the film.</P>
<P>The <A href="/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_(2010_film)" title="Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)">2010 Tim Burton adaptation</A> had much less of an effect on the park, only inspiring <A href="/wiki/Mad_T_Party" title="Mad T Party">Mad T Party</A>, a nighttime event at <A href="/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure" title="Disney California Adventure">Disney California Adventure</A>.</P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Video_games">Video games</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Alice_in_Wonderland_(1951_film)&action=edit&section=15" title="Edit section: Video games">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>In <I><A href="/wiki/Disney%27s_Villains%27_Revenge" title="Disney's Villains' Revenge">Disney's Villains' Revenge</A></I>, the Queen of Hearts is one of the villains who tries to turn the ending to her story to where she finally cuts off Alice's head. <I><A href="/wiki/Mickey_Mousecapade" title="Mickey Mousecapade">Mickey Mousecapade</A></I> features various characters from the film. The Japanese version, in fact, is based very heavily on the film, with almost every reference in the game coming from the film.</P>
<P>A video game version of the film was released on <A href="/wiki/Game_Boy_Color" title="Game Boy Color">Game Boy Color</A> by <A href="/wiki/Nintendo" title="Nintendo">Nintendo of America</A> on October 4, 2000 in North America. Additionally, in the video games <I><A href="/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts" title="Kingdom Hearts">Kingdom Hearts</A></I> and <I><A href="/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts:_Chain_of_Memories" title="Kingdom Hearts: Chain of Memories">Kingdom Hearts: Chain of Memories</A></I>, Wonderland is a playable world. Alice is also a major character in the overall plot of the first game due to her role as one of seven "Princesses of Heart". Other characters from the movie that appear include the Queen of Hearts, the Cheshire Cat, the White Rabbit, the Doorknob, the Caterpillar (<A href="/w/index.php?title=V_Cast&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="V Cast (page does not exist)">V Cast</A> only), and the Deck of Cards. The Mad Hatter and the March Hare appear in portrait form as well. All except the Doorknob also appear in <I>Chain of Memories</I>, albeit in the form of illusions made from the main character's memory.<SUP id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-26">[26]</A></SUP> While the world is absent in <I><A href="/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_II" title="Kingdom Hearts II">Kingdom Hearts II</A></I>, it returns in <I><A href="/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_358/2_Days" title="Kingdom Hearts 358/2 Days">Kingdom Hearts 358/2 Days</A></I> and <I><A href="/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_coded" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom Hearts coded">Kingdom Hearts coded</A></I>, the latter featuring a digitized version of the world originating from data in <A href="/wiki/Jiminy_Cricket" title="Jiminy Cricket">Jiminy Cricket</A>'s royal journal.</P>
<P>In <I><A href="/wiki/Toy_Story_3:_The_Video_Game" title="Toy Story 3: The Video Game">Toy Story 3: The Video Game</A></I>, the Mad Hatter's hat is one of the hats you can have the townsfolk wear. In <I><A href="/wiki/Kinect_Disneyland_Adventures" class="mw-redirect" title="Kinect Disneyland Adventures">Kinect Disneyland Adventures</A></I>, Alice, Mad Hatter, White Rabbit, and the Queen of Hearts make appearances.</P>
<P>In <I><A href="/wiki/Disney_Infinity" title="Disney Infinity">Disney Infinity</A></I> there are power discs based on Alice in Wonderland.</P>
<P>Several characters of the movie make appearances throughout the Epic Mickey-games. For example, the cards are seen throughout Mickeyjunk Mountain in the original <A href="/wiki/Epic_Mickey" title="Epic Mickey">Epic Mickey</A>, Alice appears as a statue carrying a projector screen in <A href="/wiki/Epic_Mickey_2" class="mw-redirect" title="Epic Mickey 2">Epic Mickey 2</A> and Alice, the Mad Hatter, the Cheshire Cat and the Queen of Hearts appear as unlockable characters in <A href="/wiki/Epic_Mickey:_Power_of_Illusion" title="Epic Mickey: Power of Illusion">Epic Mickey: Power of Illusion</A>.</P>

<P><I><B>Deadpool 2</B></I> is an upcoming American <A href="/wiki/Superhero_film" title="Superhero film">superhero film</A> based on the <A href="/wiki/Marvel_Comics" title="Marvel Comics">Marvel Comics</A> character <A href="/wiki/Deadpool" title="Deadpool">Deadpool</A>, distributed by <A href="/wiki/20th_Century_Fox" title="20th Century Fox">20th Century Fox</A>. It is intended to be the eleventh installment in the <A href="/wiki/X-Men_(film_series)" title="X-Men (film series)"><I>X-Men</I> film series</A>, and a sequel to the 2016 film <I><A href="/wiki/Deadpool_(film)" title="Deadpool (film)">Deadpool</A></I>. The film is directed by <A href="/wiki/David_Leitch_(director)" title="David Leitch (director)">David Leitch</A> from a script by <A href="/wiki/Rhett_Reese" title="Rhett Reese">Rhett Reese</A>, <A href="/wiki/Paul_Wernick" title="Paul Wernick">Paul Wernick</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Ryan_Reynolds" title="Ryan Reynolds">Ryan Reynolds</A>, with Reynolds starring in the title role alongside <A href="/wiki/Josh_Brolin" title="Josh Brolin">Josh Brolin</A>, <A href="/wiki/Morena_Baccarin" title="Morena Baccarin">Morena Baccarin</A>, <A href="/wiki/Julian_Dennison" title="Julian Dennison">Julian Dennison</A>, <A href="/wiki/Zazie_Beetz" title="Zazie Beetz">Zazie Beetz</A>, <A href="/wiki/T.J._Miller" title="T.J. Miller">T.J. Miller</A>, <A href="/wiki/Brianna_Hildebrand" title="Brianna Hildebrand">Brianna Hildebrand</A>, <A href="/wiki/Jack_Kesy" title="Jack Kesy">Jack Kesy</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Stefan_Kapi%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Stefan Kapičić">Stefan Kapičić</A>. In <I>Deadpool 2</I>, Deadpool forms the team <A href="/wiki/X-Force" title="X-Force">X-Force</A> to protect a young mutant from <A href="/wiki/Cable_(comics)" title="Cable (comics)">Cable</A>.</P>
<P>Plans for a sequel to <I>Deadpool</I> began before that film's release, and were confirmed in February 2016. Though the original creative team of Reynolds, Reese, Wernick, and director <A href="/wiki/Tim_Miller_(director)" title="Tim Miller (director)">Tim Miller</A> were quickly set to return for the second film, Miller left the project in October 2016 due to creative differences with Reynolds, and was soon replaced by Leitch. An extensive casting search took place to fill the role of Cable, with Brolin ultimately cast; the casting of Beetz as <A href="/wiki/Domino_(comics)" title="Domino (comics)">Domino</A> was also noteworthy. Filming took place in <A href="/wiki/British_Columbia" title="British Columbia">British Columbia</A>, Canada, from June to October 2017. During filming, stunt woman <A href="/wiki/Joi_Harris" title="Joi Harris">Joi "SJ" Harris</A> died in a motorcycle accident.</P>
<P><I>Deadpool 2</I> is scheduled to be released in the United States on May 18, 2018. A sequel, <I>Deadpool 3</I>, is in development.</P>
<P></P>

<P></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Premise">Premise</SPAN></H2>
<P><A href="/wiki/Deadpool" title="Deadpool">Deadpool</A> forms a team of mutants called the <A href="/wiki/X-Force" title="X-Force">X-Force</A> to protect young mutant Russell from the time-traveling soldier <A href="/wiki/Cable_(comics)" title="Cable (comics)">Cable</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-OfficialTrailerBreakdown_1-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OfficialTrailerBreakdown-1">[1]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-2">[2]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Cast">Cast</SPAN></H2>
<UL>
<LI><A href="/wiki/Ryan_Reynolds" title="Ryan Reynolds">Ryan Reynolds</A> as <A href="/wiki/Deadpool" title="Deadpool">Wade Wilson / Deadpool</A>:<BR />
A wisecracking mercenary with accelerated healing but severe scarring over his body after undergoing an experimental regenerative mutation.<SUP id="cite_ref-GreenLight_3-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-GreenLight-3">[3]</A></SUP> He forms the X-Force, a team of mutants.<SUP id="cite_ref-OfficialTrailerBreakdown_1-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OfficialTrailerBreakdown-1">[1]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI><A href="/wiki/Josh_Brolin" title="Josh Brolin">Josh Brolin</A> as <A href="/wiki/Cable_(comics)" title="Cable (comics)">Nathan Summers / Cable</A>:<BR />
A time travelling cybernetic mutant soldier, "in many ways the opposite of Deadpool".<SUP id="cite_ref-Brolin_4-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Brolin-4">[4]</A></SUP> Director <A href="/wiki/David_Leitch_(director)" title="David Leitch (director)">David Leitch</A> called the dynamic between Cable and Deadpool "sort of classic buddy-cop fare", and compared them to the characters portrayed by <A href="/wiki/Nick_Nolte" title="Nick Nolte">Nick Nolte</A> and <A href="/wiki/Eddie_Murphy" title="Eddie Murphy">Eddie Murphy</A>, respectively, in <I><A href="/wiki/48_Hrs." title="48 Hrs.">48 Hrs.</A></I> (1982).<SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchFandangoApr2018_5-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchFandangoApr2018-5">[5]</A></SUP> Brolin signed a four-film deal to play the character,<SUP id="cite_ref-Brolin_4-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Brolin-4">[4]</A></SUP> and described his appearance here as just the introduction for the character, with "three more movies to reveal more."<SUP id="cite_ref-BrolinOct2017_6-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-BrolinOct2017-6">[6]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI><A href="/wiki/Morena_Baccarin" title="Morena Baccarin">Morena Baccarin</A> as <A href="/wiki/Copycat_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Copycat (Marvel Comics)">Vanessa</A>: An escort and Wilson's fiancée.<SUP id="cite_ref-Baccarin_7-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Baccarin-7">[7]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI><A href="/wiki/Julian_Dennison" title="Julian Dennison">Julian Dennison</A> as Russell:<BR />
A young mutant being hunted by Cable.<SUP id="cite_ref-Dennison_8-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Dennison-8">[8]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-9">[9]</A></SUP> Dennison was the only actor that the creative team considered for the role, with Russell "sort of a tailor-made character" for the actor.<SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchFandangoApr2018_5-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchFandangoApr2018-5">[5]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI><A href="/wiki/Zazie_Beetz" title="Zazie Beetz">Zazie Beetz</A> as <A href="/wiki/Domino_(comics)" title="Domino (comics)">Neena Thurman / Domino</A>:<BR />
A mercenary with the mutant ability to manipulate <A href="/wiki/Luck" title="Luck">luck</A>,<SUP id="cite_ref-Beetz_10-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Beetz-10">[10]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-DominoCasting_11-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-DominoCasting-11">[11]</A></SUP> who joins Deadpool's X-Force team.<SUP id="cite_ref-Tan_12-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Tan-12">[12]</A></SUP> Leitch described the film's version of the character as Beetz' own "real fun interesting take".<SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchFandangoApr2018_5-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchFandangoApr2018-5">[5]</A></SUP> Beetz began "doing strength conditioning, so that's like working out everyday" when she got the role, for which she has to "be shooting guns, I fight and a lot of that movement is full body and physical."<SUP id="cite_ref-BeetzMay2017_13-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-BeetzMay2017-13">[13]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI><A href="/wiki/T.J._Miller" title="T.J. Miller">T.J. Miller</A> as <A href="/wiki/Weasel_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Weasel (Marvel Comics)">Weasel</A>: Wilson's best friend, the owner of a bar frequented by mercenaries.<SUP id="cite_ref-TJMiller_14-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-TJMiller-14">[14]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI><A href="/wiki/Brianna_Hildebrand" title="Brianna Hildebrand">Brianna Hildebrand</A> as <A href="/wiki/Negasonic_Teenage_Warhead" title="Negasonic Teenage Warhead">Negasonic Teenage Warhead</A>:<BR />
A teenage <A href="/wiki/X-Men" title="X-Men">X-Man</A> with the mutant power to detonate atomic bursts from her body,<SUP id="cite_ref-KapicicHildebrand_15-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-KapicicHildebrand-15">[15]</A></SUP> she is now a "new level of X-Men" after being a trainee in the first film.<SUP id="cite_ref-LiefeldKapicicTeaser_16-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LiefeldKapicicTeaser-16">[16]</A></SUP> Hildebrand felt that "it's cool that she's grown and matured and she still has so much of this essence of a punk kid" from the first film, and added that the character would have a "cooler" costume in the sequel.<SUP id="cite_ref-HildebrandMar2017_17-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-HildebrandMar2017-17">[17]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI><A href="/wiki/Jack_Kesy" title="Jack Kesy">Jack Kesy</A> as <A href="/wiki/Black_Tom_Cassidy" title="Black Tom Cassidy">Black Tom Cassidy</A>: A mutant who can manipulate energy through plants.<SUP id="cite_ref-Kesy_18-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Kesy-18">[18]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI><A href="/wiki/Stefan_Kapi%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Stefan Kapičić">Stefan Kapičić</A> as the voice of <A href="/wiki/Colossus_(comics)" title="Colossus (comics)">Colossus</A>:<BR />
An X-Man with the mutant ability to transform his entire body into organic steel.<SUP id="cite_ref-KapicicHildebrand_15-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-KapicicHildebrand-15">[15]</A></SUP> Kapičić described Colossus as one of the most important characters in the film, requiring a more intense process for Kapičić during recording for the character. He explained that Colossus would continue to try make Deadpool a better person and potential X-Man after doing so in the first film.<SUP id="cite_ref-KapicicCableTrailer_19-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-KapicicCableTrailer-19">[19]</A></SUP></LI>
</UL>
<P><A href="/wiki/Leslie_Uggams" title="Leslie Uggams">Leslie Uggams</A> and <A href="/wiki/Karan_Soni" title="Karan Soni">Karan Soni</A> return from the first film as Deadpool's elderly roommate <A href="/wiki/Blind_Al" title="Blind Al">Blind Al</A> and the taxi driver <A href="/wiki/Dopinder" class="mw-redirect" title="Dopinder">Dopinder</A>, respectively.<SUP id="cite_ref-Uggams_20-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Uggams-20">[20]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-Soni_21-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Soni-21">[21]</A></SUP> The X-Force team also includes <A href="/wiki/Terry_Crews" title="Terry Crews">Terry Crews</A> as <A href="/wiki/Bedlam_(comics)" title="Bedlam (comics)">Bedlam</A>,<SUP id="cite_ref-CableTrailer_22-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-CableTrailer-22">[22]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-OfficialTrailerBreakdown_1-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OfficialTrailerBreakdown-1">[1]</A></SUP> <A href="/wiki/Lewis_Tan" title="Lewis Tan">Lewis Tan</A> as <A href="/wiki/Shatterstar" title="Shatterstar">Shatterstar</A>,<SUP id="cite_ref-Tan_12-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Tan-12">[12]</A></SUP> and <A href="/wiki/Rob_Delaney" title="Rob Delaney">Rob Delaney</A> as Peter.<SUP id="cite_ref-OfficialTrailerBreakdown_1-3" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OfficialTrailerBreakdown-1">[1]</A></SUP> <A href="/wiki/Shioli_Kutsuna" class="mw-redirect" title="Shioli Kutsuna">Shioli Kutsuna</A>, <A href="/wiki/Eddie_Marsan" title="Eddie Marsan">Eddie Marsan</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Bill_Skarsg%C3%A5rd" title="Bill Skarsgård">Bill Skarsgård</A> have been cast in undisclosed roles.<SUP id="cite_ref-Kutsuna_23-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Kutsuna-23">[23]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-Marsan_24-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Marsan-24">[24]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-OfficialTrailerBreakdown_1-4" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OfficialTrailerBreakdown-1">[1]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Production">Production</SPAN></H2>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Development">Development</SPAN></H3>
<P>Producer <A href="/wiki/Simon_Kinberg" title="Simon Kinberg">Simon Kinberg</A> revealed in September 2015 that discussions had begun regarding ideas for a sequel to <I><A href="/wiki/Deadpool_(film)" title="Deadpool (film)">Deadpool</A></I>, which was set to be released in February 2016. One idea was for the film to introduce the character <A href="/wiki/Cable_(comics)" title="Cable (comics)">Cable</A>, who had previously been looked at to appear in the first <I>Deadpool</I>, and <I><A href="/wiki/X-Men:_Days_of_Future_Past" title="X-Men: Days of Future Past">X-Men: Days of Future Past</A></I> before that.<SUP id="cite_ref-KinbergColliderSep2015_25-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-KinbergColliderSep2015-25">[25]</A></SUP> Cable's inclusion in the potential sequel was confirmed by the character Deadpool, breaking the <A href="/wiki/Fourth_wall" title="Fourth wall">fourth wall</A>, in the <A href="/wiki/Post-credit_scene" class="mw-redirect" title="Post-credit scene">post-credit scene</A> of the first film. <A href="/wiki/Domino_(comics)" title="Domino (comics)">Domino</A>, a character with connections to Cable in the comics, was also believed to be featured in the sequel.<SUP id="cite_ref-DominoRumor_26-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-DominoRumor-26">[26]</A></SUP> By the first film's release, <A href="/wiki/20th_Century_Fox" title="20th Century Fox">20th Century Fox</A> had green-lit a sequel, with writers <A href="/wiki/Rhett_Reese" title="Rhett Reese">Rhett Reese</A> and <A href="/wiki/Paul_Wernick" title="Paul Wernick">Paul Wernick</A> returning to write the screenplay. Though director <A href="/wiki/Tim_Miller_(director)" title="Tim Miller (director)">Tim Miller</A> and producer/star <A href="/wiki/Ryan_Reynolds" title="Ryan Reynolds">Ryan Reynolds</A> were not confirmed for the sequel at the time, Fox was "intent on keeping the creative team together".<SUP id="cite_ref-GreenLight_3-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-GreenLight-3">[3]</A></SUP> Miller and Reynolds' involvement was confirmed at the 2016 CinemaCon that April,<SUP id="cite_ref-CinemaCon2016_27-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-CinemaCon2016-27">[27]</A></SUP> though Miller had still not formally signed on to direct the sequel yet. He began work developing the script with the writers, while Reynolds had signed a new contract granting him "casting approval and other creative controls".<SUP id="cite_ref-MillerExit2_28-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-MillerExit2-28">[28]</A></SUP></P>
<DIV class="quotebox pullquote" style="float: right; clear: right; margin: 0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em; width:33%; padding: 10px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #F9F9F9;">
<DIV class="" style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<DIV>It has to tonally and stylistically be as fresh and original [as the first film]. That's a big challenge especially because they had 10 years to gestate on the first movie and we don't have that kind of time on the second movie. That's the biggest mandate going [into] the second film ... we have to resist the temptation to make it bigger.</DIV>
</DIV>
<P><CITE style="display: block; text-align: left;">—Producer Simon Kinberg on approaching <I>Deadpool 2</I><SUP id="cite_ref-EWDec2016_29-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-EWDec2016-29">[29]</A></SUP></CITE></P>
</DIV>
<P>In June 2016, Kinberg said that a completed draft from Wernick and Rheese was expected "soon", and that they were looking to begin filming the sequel at the beginning of 2017.<SUP id="cite_ref-KinbergColliderJun2016_30-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-KinbergColliderJun2016-30">[30]</A></SUP> By August, <A href="/wiki/Kyle_Chandler" title="Kyle Chandler">Kyle Chandler</A> was believed to be in the running to portray Cable.<SUP id="cite_ref-Chandler_31-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Chandler-31">[31]</A></SUP> Testing of actresses for Domino had also begun by October, with the shortlist of actresses under consideration including <A href="/wiki/Lizzy_Caplan" title="Lizzy Caplan">Lizzy Caplan</A>, <A href="/wiki/Mary_Elizabeth_Winstead" title="Mary Elizabeth Winstead">Mary Elizabeth Winstead</A>, <A href="/wiki/Sienna_Miller" title="Sienna Miller">Sienna Miller</A>, <A href="/wiki/Sofia_Boutella" title="Sofia Boutella">Sofia Boutella</A>, <A href="/wiki/Stephanie_Sigman" title="Stephanie Sigman">Stephanie Sigman</A>, <A href="/wiki/Sylvia_Hoeks" title="Sylvia Hoeks">Sylvia Hoeks</A>, <A href="/wiki/Mackenzie_Davis" title="Mackenzie Davis">Mackenzie Davis</A>, <A href="/wiki/Ruby_Rose" title="Ruby Rose">Ruby Rose</A>, <A href="/wiki/Eve_Hewson" title="Eve Hewson">Eve Hewson</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Kelly_Rohrbach" title="Kelly Rohrbach">Kelly Rohrbach</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-DominoCasting_11-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-DominoCasting-11">[11]</A></SUP> The producers were particularly interested in casting a black or Latina actress in the role.<SUP id="cite_ref-Beetz_10-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Beetz-10">[10]</A></SUP></P>
<P>At the end of October, Miller left the film over "mutual creative differences" with Reynolds.<SUP id="cite_ref-MillerExit_32-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-MillerExit-32">[32]</A></SUP> The rift between the pair was reportedly based on several factors, including Reynolds' expanded creative control over the sequel; Miller's wish for a more stylized follow-up than the first film, versus Reynolds' focus "on the raunchy comedy style that earned the first movie its R rating"; and Miller's intention to cast Chandler as Cable, which Reynolds opposed. Fox ultimately backed "its marketable star" over Miller, who had made his <A href="/wiki/Directorial_debut" class="mw-redirect" title="Directorial debut">directorial debut</A> with the first film.<SUP id="cite_ref-MillerExit2_28-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-MillerExit2-28">[28]</A></SUP> Miller denied these reported reasons,<SUP id="cite_ref-MillerResponse_33-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-MillerResponse-33">[33]</A></SUP> while Reynolds said, "All I can really add is that I'm sad to see him off the film. Tim's brilliant and nobody worked harder on <I>Deadpool</I> than he did."<SUP id="cite_ref-ReynoldsResponseMiller_34-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ReynoldsResponseMiller-34">[34]</A></SUP> A week after Miller's departure, Fox was looking at <A href="/wiki/David_Leitch_(director)" title="David Leitch (director)">David Leitch</A>, <A href="/wiki/Drew_Goddard" title="Drew Goddard">Drew Goddard</A>, Magnus Martens, and <A href="/wiki/Rupert_Sanders" title="Rupert Sanders">Rupert Sanders</A> as potential replacements for the director.<SUP id="cite_ref-DeadlineOct2016_35-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-DeadlineOct2016-35">[35]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchConfirmed_36-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchConfirmed-36">[36]</A></SUP> Leitch was the "strong frontrunner" for the role,<SUP id="cite_ref-MashableLeitch_37-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-MashableLeitch-37">[37]</A></SUP> and signed on to direct a month later.<SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchConfirmed_36-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchConfirmed-36">[36]</A></SUP> Reynolds, a fan of Leitch's <I><A href="/wiki/John_Wick" title="John Wick">John Wick</A></I>, said the director "really understands those <I>Deadpool</I> sensibilities and where we need to take the franchise from here." He added that Leitch "can make a movie on an ultra tight minimal budget look like it was shot for 10–15 times what it cost."<SUP id="cite_ref-EWDec2016_29-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-EWDec2016-29">[29]</A></SUP></P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Pre-production">Pre-production</SPAN></H3>
<P>Reese and Wernick had completed multiple drafts of the script by January 2017, saying, "It's taken different twists and turns, but it's really coalescing"; the film was still on track to begin filming that year.<SUP id="cite_ref-ReeseWernickJan2017_38-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ReeseWernickJan2017-38">[38]</A></SUP> The pair felt a responsibility to explore the team <A href="/wiki/X-Force" title="X-Force">X-Force</A>, which includes Deadpool, Cable, and Domino in the comics, with Reese saying the sequel's purpose "is not to set up X-Force [but] it will likely set up X-Force."<SUP id="cite_ref-ReeseWernickJan2017XForce_39-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ReeseWernickJan2017XForce-39">[39]</A></SUP> He did clarify that though the film will be "populated with a lot of characters ... it is still Deadpool's movie".<SUP id="cite_ref-ReeseWernickJan2017_38-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ReeseWernickJan2017-38">[38]</A></SUP> The pair confirmed that <A href="/wiki/Stefan_Kapi%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Stefan Kapičić">Stefan Kapičić</A>'s <A href="/wiki/Colossus_(comics)" title="Colossus (comics)">Colossus</A>, <A href="/wiki/Brianna_Hildebrand" title="Brianna Hildebrand">Brianna Hildebrand</A>'s <A href="/wiki/Negasonic_Teenage_Warhead" title="Negasonic Teenage Warhead">Negasonic Teenage Warhead</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Karan_Soni" title="Karan Soni">Karan Soni</A>'s Dopinder would be returning from the first film to "make at least an appearance",<SUP id="cite_ref-KapicicHildebrand_15-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-KapicicHildebrand-15">[15]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-Soni_21-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Soni-21">[21]</A></SUP> and that the film would not be exploring the details of Cable's convoluted comic origins.<SUP id="cite_ref-ReeseWernickJan2017Cable_40-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ReeseWernickJan2017Cable-40">[40]</A></SUP> By the next month, it had been noted that there had been few announcements from Fox regarding the film, and that a release date had not yet been set which was seen as unusual for sequels to popular films (often studios "announce sequels far too soon and with no idea what will happen"), with the issue deemed to be the film's script. Reynolds, Reese, and Wernick had been "bunkered down, working on the script together, trying to cross the finish line and create something everyone is excited to make". At that time, Goddard joined the project to consult on the script.<SUP id="cite_ref-Goddard_41-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Goddard-41">[41]</A></SUP></P>
<P>By the beginning of March 2017, <A href="/wiki/Michael_Shannon" title="Michael Shannon">Michael Shannon</A> had been in the running to portray Cable, but no longer could due to a scheduling conflict.<SUP id="cite_ref-ShannonCollider_42-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ShannonCollider-42">[42]</A></SUP> <A href="/wiki/David_Harbour" title="David Harbour">David Harbour</A> had screen-tested for the role,<SUP id="cite_ref-Harbour_43-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Harbour-43">[43]</A></SUP> and <A href="/wiki/Pierce_Brosnan" title="Pierce Brosnan">Pierce Brosnan</A> was believed to be in negotiations for a part in the film, potentially Cable.<SUP id="cite_ref-Brosnan_44-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Brosnan-44">[44]</A></SUP> Reynolds announced shortly after that <A href="/wiki/Zazie_Beetz" title="Zazie Beetz">Zazie Beetz</A> had been cast as Domino.<SUP id="cite_ref-Beetz_10-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Beetz-10">[10]</A></SUP> Later in the month, Shannon was in the running to portray Cable again, and was considered the frontrunner, with Fox also looking at a shortlist of other actors that included Harbour.<SUP id="cite_ref-ShannonFrontrunner_45-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ShannonFrontrunner-45">[45]</A></SUP> <A href="/wiki/Brad_Pitt" title="Brad Pitt">Brad Pitt</A> had also been considered for the role, and expressed interest in taking it, but had "moved on".<SUP id="cite_ref-Pitt_46-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Pitt-46">[46]</A></SUP> Leitch soon addressed the potential casting of these actors, saying Shannon "would make an incredible Cable ... If that happens, I would be through the roof";<SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchShannon_47-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchShannon-47">[47]</A></SUP> and on Pitt, "We had a great meeting with Brad, he was incredibly interested in the property. Things didn't work out schedule-wise. He's a fan, and we love him, and I think he would've made an amazing Cable."<SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchPitt_48-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchPitt-48">[48]</A></SUP> At the end of March, <A href="/wiki/Morena_Baccarin" title="Morena Baccarin">Morena Baccarin</A> confirmed her return from the first film as <A href="/wiki/Copycat_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Copycat (Marvel Comics)">Vanessa</A>, and expressed interest in exploring the character's Copycat persona from the comics in the sequel.<SUP id="cite_ref-Baccarin_7-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Baccarin-7">[7]</A></SUP> <A href="/wiki/Josh_Brolin" title="Josh Brolin">Josh Brolin</A> emerged as a "surprise contender" to play Cable in April, ahead of Shannon and Harbour, and was officially cast in the role. Brolin also portrays the <A href="/wiki/Marvel_Comics" title="Marvel Comics">Marvel Comics</A> character <A href="/wiki/Thanos" title="Thanos">Thanos</A>, in the <A href="/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe" title="Marvel Cinematic Universe">Marvel Cinematic Universe</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-Brolin_4-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Brolin-4">[4]</A></SUP> <A href="/wiki/Leslie_Uggams" title="Leslie Uggams">Leslie Uggams</A> confirmed that she would be reprising her role of <A href="/wiki/Blind_Al" title="Blind Al">Blind Al</A> from the first film,<SUP id="cite_ref-Uggams_20-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Uggams-20">[20]</A></SUP> while Fox gave the sequel a June 1, 2018 release date.<SUP id="cite_ref-ReleaseDate_49-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ReleaseDate-49">[49]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Noting the release date, Leitch wanted to ensure that the film "was worthy of a summer tentpole movie, and we knew we were going to be wedged in between some big films", specifically wanting to expand the action and make the general feeling of the film "bigger" than the first one. However, he wanted the film to have the same DNA as the original "in terms of the tone, and the fun ... I love that challenge" of combining that with the increased scope. The film uses Deadpool's fourth wall-breaking to reference this release period, with Leitch calling these comments "definitely fresh and timely when they come up."<SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchFandangoApr2018_5-3" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchFandangoApr2018-5">[5]</A></SUP> In May 2017, Fox was reportedly looking to use a post-credits scene at the end of <I>Deadpool 2</I> to introduce several other members of X-Force who would go on to star alongside Reynolds, Brolin, and Beetz in an <I>X-Force</I> film. Casting for the characters—<A href="/wiki/Sunspot_(comics)" title="Sunspot (comics)">Sunspot</A>, <A href="/wiki/Feral_(comics)" title="Feral (comics)">Feral</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Shatterstar" title="Shatterstar">Shatterstar</A>—would take place over the coming months, though Reese denied the accuracy of this report.<SUP id="cite_ref-XForce3_50-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-XForce3-50">[50]</A></SUP> Later, <A href="/wiki/T.J._Miller" title="T.J. Miller">T.J. Miller</A> confirmed that he would return from the first film as <A href="/wiki/Weasel_(Marvel_Comics)" title="Weasel (Marvel Comics)">Weasel</A>, and described the sequel as "even more weaselicious" than the first. He noted that Reynolds and the writers had "really put the time in on the script" to meet their own expectations for the sequel as well as those of fans.<SUP id="cite_ref-TJMiller_14-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-TJMiller-14">[14]</A></SUP> <A href="/wiki/Jack_Kesy" title="Jack Kesy">Jack Kesy</A> also joined the cast, as <A href="/wiki/Black_Tom_Cassidy" title="Black Tom Cassidy">Black Tom Cassidy</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-Kesy_18-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Kesy-18">[18]</A></SUP> In June, <A href="/wiki/Shioli_Kutsuna" class="mw-redirect" title="Shioli Kutsuna">Shioli Kutsuna</A> was cast in a key role for the film.<SUP id="cite_ref-Kutsuna_23-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Kutsuna-23">[23]</A></SUP></P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Filming">Filming</SPAN></H3>
<P>Initial filming had begun by June 17, 2017, at <A href="/wiki/Hatley_Park_National_Historic_Site#Hatley_Castle_and_Gardens" title="Hatley Park National Historic Site">Hatley Castle</A> in Victoria, Canada, which is used to portray the <A href="/wiki/X-Mansion" title="X-Mansion">X-Mansion</A> in the <I>X-Men</I> films.<SUP id="cite_ref-HatleyFilming_51-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-HatleyFilming-51">[51]</A></SUP> <A href="/wiki/Principal_photography" title="Principal photography">Principal photography</A> began in <A href="/wiki/Vancouver" title="Vancouver">Vancouver</A> on June 26, under the <A href="/wiki/Working_title" title="Working title">working title</A> <I>Love Machine</I>.<SUP id="cite_ref-ProductionDates_52-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ProductionDates-52">[52]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-WorkingTitle_53-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-WorkingTitle-53">[53]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-Sela_54-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Sela-54">[54]</A></SUP> <A href="/wiki/Jonathan_Sela" title="Jonathan Sela">Jonathan Sela</A> served as cinematographer for the film.<SUP id="cite_ref-Sela_54-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Sela-54">[54]</A></SUP> At the end of June, Reynolds revealed that <A href="/wiki/Julian_Dennison" title="Julian Dennison">Julian Dennison</A> had been cast in the film.<SUP id="cite_ref-Dennison_8-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Dennison-8">[8]</A></SUP> The next month, T. J. Miller said that he found the sequel to be funnier than the first film, and that "it's not going to be the same movie in a different location [like <I><A href="/wiki/The_Hangover_Part_II" title="The Hangover Part II">The Hangover Part II</A></I>]. It's got different stakes, different things happen, some pretty tragic, dark shit happens in the first part of the film, in the beginning, and the rest of the film is kind of dealing with that."<SUP id="cite_ref-MillerJul2017_55-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-MillerJul2017-55">[55]</A></SUP> By then, Kapičić had been working with Leitch on the set, and expected to continue contributing to Colossus through to April 2018.<SUP id="cite_ref-KapicicJul2017_56-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-KapicicJul2017-56">[56]</A></SUP></P>
<P>On August 14, stunt woman <A href="/wiki/Joi_Harris" title="Joi Harris">Joi "SJ" Harris</A> died in a motorcycle accident after losing control and crashing into <A href="/wiki/Shaw_Tower_(Vancouver)" title="Shaw Tower (Vancouver)">Shaw Tower</A>. Harris, the first African-American female professional road racer, was working on the film as a stunt performer for the first time and had only joined the production a week before. Harris was not wearing a helmet because the character she was portraying, Domino, does not wear one in the scene, and there had not been time since she joined the film to create one for her to fit underneath the Domino wig. She had two full days of rehearsing the stunt as well as five more attempts on the day of the accident.<SUP id="cite_ref-StuntWomanDeath_57-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-StuntWomanDeath-57">[57]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-ProductionRestart_58-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ProductionRestart-58">[58]</A></SUP> Veteran stunt double Melissa Stubbs had been available and willing to do the stunt, but the inexperienced Harris was preferred due to her skin color being a match for Beetz. This decision was criticized by multiple stunt professionals, with many noting that Harris' experiences racing motorcycles did not necessarily qualify her as an able stunt performer.<SUP id="cite_ref-HarrisTHR_59-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-HarrisTHR-59">[59]</A></SUP> Production on the film was shut down immediately after the incident, but resumed two days later. With this news also came reports that the film's crew were "enduring very long hours" and were "exhausted by the schedule", with a member of the studio confirming that some days had gone beyond the scheduled 12–13 hours filming, up to 15–plus hours.<SUP id="cite_ref-StuntWomanDeath_57-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-StuntWomanDeath-57">[57]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-ProductionRestart_58-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ProductionRestart-58">[58]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Earlier in August, Reynolds revealed that <A href="/wiki/Rob_Delaney" title="Rob Delaney">Rob Delaney</A> was at the film's set,<SUP id="cite_ref-Delaney_60-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Delaney-60">[60]</A></SUP> and <A href="/wiki/Eddie_Marsan" title="Eddie Marsan">Eddie Marsan</A> revealed that he was also on set for a role in the film later in the month.<SUP id="cite_ref-Marsan_24-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Marsan-24">[24]</A></SUP> Filming in Vancouver was expected to last until October 6,<SUP id="cite_ref-ProductionDates_52-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ProductionDates-52">[52]</A></SUP> with production on <I>Deadpool 2</I> being officially completed on October 14.<SUP id="cite_ref-FilmingEnds_61-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-FilmingEnds-61">[61]</A></SUP> Discussing the film's action, having previously worked as a stunt coordinator, Leitch said that all stunts are "variations on a theme" with the same basic elements, but Deadpool allows you to "subvert those basics, and there's an expectation for a classic gag, but oops, maybe you get something else." He also felt that introducing Domino gave the film unique opportunities for action sequences taking advantage of her luck-based abilities, as well as focusing on Deadpool's healing abilities and trying to use those to create interesting action.<SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchFandangoApr2018_5-4" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchFandangoApr2018-5">[5]</A></SUP></P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Post-production">Post-production</SPAN></H3>
<P>Fox revealed in November that the film was technically untitled at that point, and not officially known as <I>Deadpool 2</I> as had been assumed; the studio was temporarily referring to the film as <I>The Untitled Deadpool Sequel</I>.<SUP id="cite_ref-Untitled_62-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Untitled-62">[62]</A></SUP> In January 2018, the film's release was moved up to May 18, 2018.<SUP id="cite_ref-Jan2018ReleaseChange_63-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Jan2018ReleaseChange-63">[63]</A></SUP> A month later, <A href="/wiki/Terry_Crews" title="Terry Crews">Terry Crews</A> was revealed to have a role in the film,<SUP id="cite_ref-CableTrailer_22-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-CableTrailer-22">[22]</A></SUP> the character Shatterstar was confirmed to be appearing,<SUP id="cite_ref-KapicicCableTrailer_19-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-KapicicCableTrailer-19">[19]</A></SUP> and the production returned to Vancouver for six days of reshoots under a new working title, <I>Daisy</I>.<SUP id="cite_ref-Reshoots_64-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Reshoots-64">[64]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-THRReshoots_65-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-THRReshoots-65">[65]</A></SUP></P>
<P>While some reports emerged by mid-March claiming that the reshoots were due to poor audience responses during test screenings of the film, and consisted of sweeping changes,<SUP id="cite_ref-ReshootReports_66-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ReshootReports-66">[66]</A></SUP> the film was soon confirmed to be testing better than the original did, up to 98 out of 100 over three different tests (compared to a maximum score of 91 during tests of the first film). Because of this, the reshoots were adding more of the elements that audiences responded positively to, including additional material featuring Cable and Domino.<SUP id="cite_ref-ReshootReports_66-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ReshootReports-66">[66]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-THRReshoots_65-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-THRReshoots-65">[65]</A></SUP> By the end of the month, two hours-worth of filming had taken place in Los Angeles for a then-secret cameo appearance,<SUP id="cite_ref-THRReshoots_65-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-THRReshoots-65">[65]</A></SUP> and the film's first full trailer was released.<SUP id="cite_ref-OfficialTrailerBreakdown_1-5" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OfficialTrailerBreakdown-1">[1]</A></SUP> Officially titling the film <I>Deadpool 2</I>,<SUP id="cite_ref-OfficialTrailer_67-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OfficialTrailer-67">[67]</A></SUP> the trailer also revealed that Crews was portraying <A href="/wiki/Bedlam_(comics)" title="Bedlam (comics)">Bedlam</A>; that Delaney was in the film, portraying Peter; and that <A href="/wiki/Bill_Skarsg%C3%A5rd" title="Bill Skarsgård">Bill Skarsgård</A> also had a role.<SUP id="cite_ref-OfficialTrailerBreakdown_1-6" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OfficialTrailerBreakdown-1">[1]</A></SUP> The film's final trailer, released a month later, confirmed that <A href="/wiki/Lewis_Tan" title="Lewis Tan">Lewis Tan</A> would portray Shatterstar, joining Domino, Bedlam, and Peter as members of the <I>X-Force</I> in the film.<SUP id="cite_ref-Tan_12-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Tan-12">[12]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</SPAN></H2>
<P><I>Deadpool</I> composer <A href="/wiki/Junkie_XL" title="Junkie XL">Junkie XL</A> chose not to return for the sequel due to Miller's departure.<SUP id="cite_ref-JunkieXL_68-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-JunkieXL-68">[68]</A></SUP> In October 2017, <A href="/wiki/Tyler_Bates" title="Tyler Bates">Tyler Bates</A> was hired to write the score for the film.<SUP id="cite_ref-Bates_69-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Bates-69">[69]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Release">Release</SPAN></H2>
<P><I>Deadpool 2</I> is set to be released in the United States on May 18, 2018.<SUP id="cite_ref-Jan2018ReleaseChange_63-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Jan2018ReleaseChange-63">[63]</A></SUP> It was previously scheduled for release on June 1 of that year.<SUP id="cite_ref-ReleaseDate_49-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ReleaseDate-49">[49]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-Untitled_62-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Untitled-62">[62]</A></SUP></P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Marketing">Marketing</SPAN></H3>
<P>For the Fox presentation at CineEurope 2017 in June, Reynolds made a video message featuring himself in costume as Deadpool from the film's set.<SUP id="cite_ref-CineEurope2017_70-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-CineEurope2017-70">[70]</A></SUP> The first teaser poster, which pays homage to <A href="/wiki/Norman_Rockwell" title="Norman Rockwell">Norman Rockwell</A>'s 1943 painting <I><A href="/wiki/Freedom_from_Want_(painting)" title="Freedom from Want (painting)">Freedom from Want</A></I>, was released that November. Justin Carter of <A href="/wiki/Comic_Book_Resources" title="Comic Book Resources">Comic Book Resources</A> found it "oddly appropriate for <I>Deadpool 2</I> to co-opt [this] iconic work for a modern pop culture audience" as it is "true to Deadpool's incredibly referential nature."<SUP id="cite_ref-CBRTeaserPoster_71-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-CBRTeaserPoster-71">[71]</A></SUP> Eric Diaz of <A href="/wiki/Nerdist_Industries" title="Nerdist Industries">Nerdist</A> said, "It strikes exactly the irreverent tone you'd expect for the <I>Deadpool</I> sequel."<SUP id="cite_ref-NerdistTeaserPoster_72-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-NerdistTeaserPoster-72">[72]</A></SUP> The first footage from the film debuted the following week, at the end of a video where Reynolds (in-character as Deadpool) parodies <A href="/wiki/Bob_Ross" title="Bob Ross">Bob Ross</A> and his television show <I><A href="/wiki/The_Joy_of_Painting" title="The Joy of Painting">The Joy of Painting</A></I>.<SUP id="cite_ref-VergeTeaser_73-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-VergeTeaser-73">[73]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-LiefeldKapicicTeaser_16-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LiefeldKapicicTeaser-16">[16]</A></SUP> The video was described by <I><A href="/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" title="The Hollywood Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</A></I><SPAN class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</SPAN>s Ryan Parker as "completely out of left field" and setting the tone perfectly for the film, though his colleague Graeme McMillan was less positive due to not knowing of Ross (<I>Deadpool</I> co-creator <A href="/wiki/Fabian_Nicieza" title="Fabian Nicieza">Fabian Nicieza</A> thought the fact that many in the audience wouldn't know of Ross made the video "exactly the kind of quirky pop culture choice that works perfectly for <I>Deadpool</I>"). Parker added, "This trailer only showed a few seconds from the film, but fans will be talking about it all day" because of the presentation, unlike "any other trailer which would have shown so little of the product."<SUP id="cite_ref-THRTeaser_74-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-THRTeaser-74">[74]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Rather than pay for an expensive advertisement spot during <A href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_LII" title="Super Bowl LII">Super Bowl LII</A>, the film's official <A href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</A> account was used to "live tweet" the event with commentary as if the character Deadpool was watching it.<SUP id="cite_ref-SuperBowl_75-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-SuperBowl-75">[75]</A></SUP> A new trailer for the film was released later that week, focusing on introducing Cable. Parker felt that "Reynolds and company have completely changed the trailer game. The formula of just showing some of the actual movie, but with a tiny story thrown in is such an incredible marketing idea." McMillan and their colleague Aaron Couch praised the trailer playing on the visual effects for Cable's arm not being finished, noting it as a joke about the visual effects to remove <A href="/wiki/Henry_Cavill" title="Henry Cavill">Henry Cavill</A>'s mustache from <I><A href="/wiki/Justice_League_(film)" title="Justice League (film)">Justice League</A></I>. The group collectively praised the overall marketing for the franchise, with McMillan suggesting that the campaign for the sequel may surpass that of the first <I>Deadpool</I>.<SUP id="cite_ref-CableTrailer_22-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-CableTrailer-22">[22]</A></SUP> A full trailer for the film, explaining its general plot, was released at the end of March. <I><A href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</A></I> contributor Scott Mendelson called it "pretty funny and mostly entertaining", but was disappointed in it being a "conventional" trailer compared to the more out-there videos previously released for the film. He explained that he thought the first film "had a winning lead character and fine character-centric jokes, but a pretty generic origin story plot that eventually became the thing it was critiquing", and was concerned that the sequel would turn out to be "a more standard 'superhero sequel' sell". Mendelson also noted the inclusion of T.J. Miller in the trailer following the reveal of <A href="/wiki/T.J._Miller#Sexual_misconduct_allegations" title="T.J. Miller">sexual misconduct allegations against the actor</A> in late 2017, calling it "inevitable no matter how tarnished his reputation might be these days."<SUP id="cite_ref-OfficialTrailerForbes_76-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OfficialTrailerForbes-76">[76]</A></SUP> The <I>Hollywood Reporter</I> group also noted the more traditional style of the trailer, but remained generally positive about the film and highlighted the supporting cast for the film as appearing in the trailer, including Brolin, Beetz, Kutsuna, and Crews.<SUP id="cite_ref-OfficialTrailerTHR_77-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OfficialTrailerTHR-77">[77]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Also in March, a Twitter account was established for the character Peter and began to be regularly updated with "tweets" about his interests, including photos of the character <A href="/wiki/Beekeeping" title="Beekeeping">beekeeping</A> and preparing for his work as part of the <I>X-Force</I> team (as seen in the film).<SUP id="cite_ref-PeterTwitter_78-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-PeterTwitter-78">[78]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-io9PeterTwitter_79-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-io9PeterTwitter-79">[79]</A></SUP> A month later, Fox released the final trailer for the film, with Mendelson lamenting that it was as "conventional" as the previous trailer but finding it understandable that Fox not be seen to be hiding the film, and ultimately felt that the trailer indicated the film would be "a pretty solid comic book sequel".<SUP id="cite_ref-FinalTrailerForbes_80-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-FinalTrailerForbes-80">[80]</A></SUP> The group at <I>The Hollywood Reporter</I> praised the final trailer as well, highlighting its references to <I><A href="/wiki/X-Men_Origins:_Wolverine" title="X-Men Origins: Wolverine">X-Men Origins: Wolverine</A></I> and the <A href="/wiki/DC_Extended_Universe" title="DC Extended Universe">DC universe</A> as well as its introduction of Peter.<SUP id="cite_ref-FinalTrailerTHR_81-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-FinalTrailerTHR-81">[81]</A></SUP> At the end of April, Leitch stated that alternate versions of jokes that had been cut from the film were included in the trailers, since "only one can live in the movie, so we might have snuck a couple in sort of additional materials that people can discover."<SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchFandangoApr2018_5-5" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchFandangoApr2018-5">[5]</A></SUP> As part of a promotion for the film with beverage company Mike's Harder, Sister Margaret’s School for Wayward Girls—the fictional bar featured in the films—will be emulated in pop-ups at the Alligator Lounge in New York from April 26–28 and the Slipper Clutch in Los Angeles from May 10–12. The pop-ups will respectively serve pizza and <A href="/wiki/Chimichanga" title="Chimichanga">chimichangas</A>, traditionally Deadpool's favorite food, as well as <I>Deadpool</I>-inspired Harder drinks. The campaign also includes the chance to win a trip to the film's premiere through Harder, and the Los Angeles pop-up will benefit the nonprofit DTLA Film Festival.<SUP id="cite_ref-HarderPromotion_82-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-HarderPromotion-82">[82]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Box_office_projection">Box office projection</SPAN></H2>
<P>Initial box office projections for the film in March 2018 expected it to gross $100 million over its opening weekend in the United States and Canada, with a final domestic total expected to be lower than that of the first film ($363 million) at around $242 million.<SUP id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-83">[83]</A></SUP> On April 20, 2018, both <A href="/wiki/Fandango_(company)" title="Fandango (company)">Fandango</A> and <A href="/wiki/Regal_Entertainment_Group" title="Regal Entertainment Group">Regal Cinemas</A> announced that <I>Deadpool 2</I> was the best pre-selling R-rated film in their respective histories.<SUP id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-84">[84]</A></SUP> By April 26, opening weekend industry projections had reached upwards of $150 million.<SUP id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-85">[85]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Sequel">Sequel</SPAN></H2>
<P>By November 2016, with development underway on <I>Deadpool 2</I>, Fox was also planning <I>Deadpool 3</I>, which was said to include the team <A href="/wiki/X-Force" title="X-Force">X-Force</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-UniversePlans_86-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-UniversePlans-86">[86]</A></SUP> With the confirmation that Leitch would direct <I>Deadpool 2</I>, it was revealed that Fox was looking for a separate filmmaker to direct <I>Deadpool 3</I>.<SUP id="cite_ref-LeitchConfirmed_36-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-LeitchConfirmed-36">[36]</A></SUP> In March 2017, Reese clarified that though <I>Deadpool 2</I> sets-up the X-Force team, a future film focused on the team would be separate from <I>Deadpool 3</I>, "so I think we'll be able to take two paths. [<I>X-Force</I>] is where we're launching something bigger, but then [<I>Deadpool 3</I> is] where we're contracting and staying personal and small."<SUP id="cite_ref-ReeseMar2017_87-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ReeseMar2017-87">[87]</A></SUP> After the <A href="/wiki/Proposed_acquisition_of_21st_Century_Fox_by_Disney" title="Proposed acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney">proposed acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney</A> was announced in December 2017, Disney CEO <A href="/wiki/Bob_Iger" title="Bob Iger">Bob Iger</A> said that Deadpool would be integrated with the <A href="/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe" title="Marvel Cinematic Universe">Marvel Cinematic Universe</A> under Disney,<SUP id="cite_ref-DisneyFoxMCU_88-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-DisneyFoxMCU-88">[88]</A></SUP> and that the company would be willing to make future R-rated Deadpool films "as long as we let the audiences know what's coming".<SUP id="cite_ref-DisneyMarvelR_89-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-DisneyMarvelR-89">[89]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="References">References</SPAN></H2>

<DIV class="thumb tright">

<DIV class="thumbcaption">

Map of central and southern <A href="/wiki/Sentinel_Range" title="Sentinel Range">Sentinel Range</A>, <A href="/wiki/Ellsworth_Mountains" title="Ellsworth Mountains">Ellsworth Mountains</A> with Vinson Massif.</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P><B>Vinson Massif</B> (<SPAN class="nowrap"><SPAN class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><A href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<SPAN style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><SPAN title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</SPAN><SPAN title="'v' in 'vie'">v</SPAN><SPAN title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</SPAN><SPAN title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</SPAN><SPAN title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</SPAN><SPAN title="/ən/: 'on' in 'button'">ən</SPAN></SPAN> <SPAN style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><SPAN title="'m' in 'my'">m</SPAN><SPAN title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</SPAN><SPAN title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</SPAN><SPAN title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</SPAN><SPAN title="/iː/: 'ee' in 'fleece'">iː</SPAN><SPAN title="'f' in 'find'">f</SPAN></SPAN>/</A></SPAN></SPAN>) is a large mountain <A href="/wiki/Massif" title="Massif">massif</A> in <A href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</A> that is 21 km (13 mi) long and 13 km (8.1 mi) wide and lies within the <A href="/wiki/Sentinel_Range" title="Sentinel Range">Sentinel Range</A> of the <A href="/wiki/Ellsworth_Mountains" title="Ellsworth Mountains">Ellsworth Mountains</A>. It overlooks the <A href="/wiki/Ronne_Ice_Shelf" class="mw-redirect" title="Ronne Ice Shelf">Ronne Ice Shelf</A> near the base of the <A href="/wiki/Antarctic_Peninsula" title="Antarctic Peninsula">Antarctic Peninsula</A>. The <A href="/wiki/Massif" title="Massif">massif</A> is located about 1,200 kilometres (750 mi) from the <A href="/wiki/South_Pole" title="South Pole">South Pole</A>. Vinson Massif was discovered in January 1958 by U.S. Navy aircraft. In 1961, the Vinson Massif was named by the <A href="/wiki/Advisory_Committee_on_Antarctic_Names" title="Advisory Committee on Antarctic Names">Advisory Committee on Antarctic Names</A> (US-ACAN), for <A href="/wiki/Carl_Vinson" title="Carl Vinson">Carl G. Vinson</A>, United States congressman from the state of Georgia, for his support for Antarctic exploration. On Nov. 1, 2006, US-ACAN declared Mount Vinson and Vinson Massif to be separate entities.<SUP id="cite_ref-gnis_4-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-gnis-4">[4]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-Stewart2011a_5-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Stewart2011a-5">[5]</A></SUP></P>
<P><B>Mount Vinson</B> is the highest peak in Antarctica, at 4,892 metres (16,050 ft). It lies in the north part of Vinson Massif’s summit plateau in the south portion of the main ridge of the Sentinel Range about 2 kilometres (1.2 mi) north of Hollister Peak.<SUP id="cite_ref-Stewart2011a_5-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Stewart2011a-5">[5]</A></SUP> It was first climbed in 1966 by an American team led by <A href="/wiki/Nicholas_Clinch" title="Nicholas Clinch">Nicholas Clinch</A>. An expedition in 2001 was the first to climb via the Eastern route, and also took GPS measurements of the height of the peak.<SUP id="cite_ref-nova_6-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-nova-6">[6]</A></SUP> As of February 2010, 1,400 climbers have attempted to reach the top of Mount Vinson.<SUP id="cite_ref-7summits_7-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-7summits-7">[7]</A></SUP></P>
<P></P>
