<P></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Synopsis">Synopsis</SPAN></H2>
<P>One day, 98% of Earth's population suddenly disappeared, and the remaining population found the skies covered in dense clouds, creating chaotic storms that dropped husks, humanoid zombie-like creatures, that attacked the living. The survivors found ways to construct "storm shields", a field that cleared the storm clouds from immediately overhead and reduced the attacks from husks, and used these to set up survivor bases across the globe. The player is a commander of one of these bases, charged with going out of the storm shield to find resources, survivors, and other allies to help expand their storm shield and find a way to return Earth to its normal state.</P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Gameplay">Gameplay</SPAN></H2>
<P>Currently, the paid-for product <I>Fortnite</I> provides two distinct modes: access to <I><A href="/wiki/Fortnite_Battle_Royale" title="Fortnite Battle Royale">Fortnite Battle Royale</A></I>, (which is also available as a separate free-to-play title) and the cooperative player-versus-environment "Save the World", which is unique to the main <I>Fortnite</I> game.</P>
<P>The "Save the World" mode is described as a co-op sandbox survival game and is about exploration, scavenging items, crafting weapons, building fortified structures, and fighting waves of encroaching monsters.<SUP id="cite_ref-ue4_5-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ue4-5">[4]</A></SUP> <A href="/wiki/Tim_Sweeney_(game_developer)" title="Tim Sweeney (game developer)">Tim Sweeney</A>, Epic's founder, described the game as "<I><A href="/wiki/Minecraft" title="Minecraft">Minecraft</A></I> meets <I><A href="/wiki/Left_4_Dead" title="Left 4 Dead">Left 4 Dead</A></I>".<SUP id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-6">[5]</A></SUP> The game cycles between managing one's resources at a safe home base, and then going out on missions to complete quests as to collect resources and obtain rewards to advance the game's story.</P>
<P>In the meta-game, the player has an inventory of weapon and trap schematics, hero characters, defender characters, and support characters, along with collected resources. Schematics are used to construct weapons and traps when on the field. Hero characters represent characters from one of four classes that the player can use while on a mission, as well as used to undertake resource-gathering missions making them unavailable to use until they return from the mission. Defender characters can be summoned to help with defense but only if there are less than four players on a mission. Support characters are used to form various non-playable squads that provide passive bonuses to the player's attack strength, building speed, armor, and health, with additional benefits if the player can match certain characterization attributes within a squad. The player can spend different types of <A href="/wiki/Experience_point" title="Experience point">experience points</A> and resources earned as mission rewards, from <A href="/wiki/Loot_box" title="Loot box">loot boxes</A> (represented as <A href="/wiki/Llama" title="Llama">llama</A> <A href="/wiki/Pinata" class="mw-redirect" title="Pinata">pinatas</A>), or other sources to level up and evolve schematics and characters. For weapons and traps, this generally boosts their effectiveness as well as unlocking additional attribute bonuses, while leveling up hero characters will unlock special skills the character has while in the field. Schematics and characters are generally assigned a rarity, which determines how much they can be leveled and evolved. A player's inventory of schematics and characters is limited, but players can opt to slot anyone they do not need into a collection book to gain rewards when certain collection sets are completed; use one or more of these schematics or characters to transform them into a new random item, or simply retire them to gain back experience points and other resources to free up the inventory slots.<SUP id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-7">[6]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-GI_on_gameplay_8-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-GI_on_gameplay-8">[7]</A></SUP></P>
<P>The player also can spend skill points, earned by completing missions, and technology points, earned over time, to unlock new skills and technologies in the game's skill and technologies trees. These can improve a player's base attributes, attributes that are shared with the other players while on missions, unlock higher levels of evolution for schematics and characters, open up new squad positions, or unlock general skills that players can use in the field. Collectively, the player's progress on these skill and technology trees, their squad composition, and their selected hero character make up the player's current "power level" which relates to what difficulty of missions the player should take and the game's matchmaking services. Also, players can review their current story progress and quests, which can include daily, side, and event quests, which when completed provide in-game currency or resources.</P>
<P>Mission is currently divided between four world locations, some available only after progressing far enough in the story, and special locations for timed events and for the Survive the Storm mode. Within a location are several possible mission areas that show the type of mission, the terrain it takes place on, its difficulty rating relative to the player's current power level, and whether the mission is currently under special "storm" conditions that throw random effects, like buffed husks or mini-bosses, into the mission but have potentially better rewards if completed. The player optionally can select a special site that automatically matches them with players at a similar power level and story progression on a random mission for added rewards.</P>
<P>Most missions take place on procedurally-generated landscapes. Most missions are based on locating site(s) representing the objectives on the map, build up fortifications around those locations, and then face off against several waves of husks that will try to destroy the objectives. During completion of these missions, players are generally given a "storm forecast" to know where husks will spawn in as to enhance fortification in that direction, though this direction can change in more difficult missions. Other missions are time-limited, requiring the players to locate and help a number of survivors, build out several radar towers, or clear out various encampment of husks scattered around the map before time runs out. These missions encourage the players to explore the map and farm for resources (either by searching objects or destroying them with an axe) used to build the fortifications, weapons, ammunition, and traps needed to defend or attack the husks. Players also frequently need to seek out bluglo, a special resource that does not carry over between maps to activate certain mission objectives. Some missions are considered a loss if the objective is destroyed or time runs out, while other missions allow the players to rework their fortifications and start their defense again if the objective is destroyed. Maps will frequently have optional objectives that are discovered through exploration, such as human survivors that need help. Completing these successfully earn immediate in-game rewards such as resources, weapons, and traps. Missions themselves may provide bonus objectives, such as by completing the mission within a certain in-game period, using a limited number of fortification pieces, or saving more survivors than the minimum necessary, which affects the qualify of rewards the players receive after the successful completion of the main mission.</P>
<P>During missions, players can make their fortifications from one of three base materials (wood, brick, and metal), and in a number of configurations, including floors/ceilings, walls, stairs, and ramps; players have the ability to edit these for more configurations, such as adding a door or window to a wall. Each fortification part can be upgraded with more resources of the same type to improve their durability, and when they are damaged, can be repaired by spending additional resources. Traps, which have a limited number of activation before they fall apart, can be placed on floors, walls, and ceilings, and arranged in means to make them more lethal or effective against husks. Traps may also include beneficial resources for players, such as healing pads, defender posts, and launch pads. Similarly, players can use a range of weapons but these have limited durability that drops as they are used or as a penalty if the player should be downed by husks and need to respawn without the help of allies. Players can construct new weapons, ammo, and traps from gathered resources, or find these from searching containers across the map. During missions, the game progresses through an accelerated day-night cycle; during the day, the husks are more passive and do not generally pose immediate threats, while during the night, bands of husks may spawn in and will aggressively seek out players.</P>
<P>One unique mission type is Storm Shield Defense missions. In each of the four world locations, the player is allocated a map that remains persistent, representing the site where their base's storm shield generator is placed, and in the storm mode, the player must return to this map to expand the storm shield, requiring them to add a new objective to defend successfully to continue the story. At any time, the player can enter this map without starting the defense mission, and use their carried-over resources to build out the fortification and traps, or add resources to a special storage area for this map.</P>
<P><I>Fortnite</I> is also able to offer themed-events with a unique progression line, new locations, and rewards based on those themes. The first such event was its <A href="/wiki/Halloween" title="Halloween">Halloween</A> event, "Fortnitemares", that offered Halloween-themed heroes, characters, weapons, and traps (usable outside of the event) by completing numerous objectives.<SUP id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-9">[8]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Development">Development</SPAN></H2>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="History">History</SPAN></H3>
<P><I>Fortnite</I> was first revealed at the 2011 <A href="/wiki/Spike_Video_Game_Awards" title="Spike Video Game Awards">Spike Video Game Awards</A> (VGA), with Epic's former design director <A href="/wiki/Cliff_Bleszinski" title="Cliff Bleszinski">Cliff Bleszinski</A> introducing a trailer for the game.<SUP id="cite_ref-forbes_10-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-forbes-10">[9]</A></SUP> Donald Mustard, creative lead at Epic, said in 2017 that this announcement was "three weeks after we came up with the idea, before we even made the game".<SUP id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-11">[10]</A></SUP> The title, which started out as an internal <A href="/wiki/Game_jam" title="Game jam">game jam</A> project,<SUP id="cite_ref-polygon_march2014_12-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-polygon_march2014-12">[11]</A></SUP> represents a departure from the company's previous work.<SUP id="cite_ref-forbes_10-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-forbes-10">[9]</A></SUP> As Bleszinski explained during the Spike event, Epic wanted to "switch things up a little bit and do something different and fun" with <I>Fortnite</I>, describing it as "a world where you explore, you scavenge, you build and ultimately you survive."<SUP id="cite_ref-forbes_10-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-forbes-10">[9]</A></SUP> In an interview with <I><A href="/wiki/Engadget" title="Engadget">Engadget</A></I>, he also echoed these statements, claiming that the game would be different from the <I><A href="/wiki/Gears_of_War" title="Gears of War">Gears of War</A></I> series: "There's no dudebros in it...Not that there's anything wrong with that, right? But creatively for the team, Gears has been amazing for us. But it's fun to kind of stretch our wings and do something that's a little different from the usual."<SUP id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-13">[12]</A></SUP> Epic Games Vice President of Publishing Mike Fischer said in 2015 that Epic recognized that they "announced this game too soon", and that its lengthy development period was due to "very good reasons."<SUP id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-14">[13]</A></SUP></P>
<P>As the game was at its very preliminary stages at the VGA reveal, the goal of this reveal was to seek public interest in the title and potential publishing partners as to decide on the game's release platforms and timeframe.<SUP id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-15">[14]</A></SUP> During the July 2012 <A href="/wiki/San_Diego_Comic_Con" class="mw-redirect" title="San Diego Comic Con">San Diego Comic Con</A>, Epic announced that <I>Fortnite</I> would be an exclusive personal computer title, and the first one to be developed by Epic using their new <A href="/wiki/Unreal_Engine" title="Unreal Engine">Unreal 4</A> game engine, with a planned release in 2013.<SUP id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-16">[15]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-17">[16]</A></SUP> The game's development was originally started in the Unreal 3 engine, but as they progressed, they had seen the opportunity to work in several of the new feature sets and scripting language offered by Unreal 4 for <I>Fortnite</I>, while still running on most personal computers at that time. They further opted for personal computer exclusivity to avoid the difficulty of having to go through console certification, and as they planned to be constantly monitoring and tweaking the game, acting as a <A href="/wiki/Dungeon_master" class="mw-redirect" title="Dungeon master">dungeon master</A>, the personal computer approach would allow them to do this without restrictions normally set by console manfuctures.<SUP id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-18">[17]</A></SUP> Bleszinski later clarified that they would not rule out release on other platforms as they developed the title.<SUP id="cite_ref-eurgamer_Sept2012_19-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-eurgamer_Sept2012-19">[18]</A></SUP></P>
<DIV class="thumb tright">
<DIV class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;"><A href="/wiki/File:Fortnite_cosplayers_at_Gamescom_2017_(2).jpg" class="image"><IMG alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Fortnite_cosplayers_at_Gamescom_2017_%282%29.jpg/230px-Fortnite_cosplayers_at_Gamescom_2017_%282%29.jpg" width="230" height="259" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Fortnite_cosplayers_at_Gamescom_2017_%282%29.jpg/345px-Fortnite_cosplayers_at_Gamescom_2017_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Fortnite_cosplayers_at_Gamescom_2017_%282%29.jpg/460px-Fortnite_cosplayers_at_Gamescom_2017_%282%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5327" data-file-height="6000" /></A>
<DIV class="thumbcaption">
<DIV class="magnify"><A href="/wiki/File:Fortnite_cosplayers_at_Gamescom_2017_(2).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></A></DIV>
<I>Fortnite</I> cosplayers at <A href="/wiki/Gamescom" title="Gamescom">Gamescom</A> 2017</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P><I>Fortnite</I><SPAN class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</SPAN>s development was spread among several of Epic's satellite studios,<SUP id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-20">[19]</A></SUP> and was also co-developed by the Polish studio <A href="/wiki/People_Can_Fly" title="People Can Fly">People Can Fly</A>, which had worked with Epic previously on earlier games, and had been fully acquired by Epic sometime in 2012. People Can Fly were briefly renamed Epic Games Poland in 2013 as to align with Epic's other studios.<SUP id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-21">[20]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-22">[21]</A></SUP> By March 2014, there were about 90 developers working on the game.<SUP id="cite_ref-polygon_march2014_12-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-polygon_march2014-12">[11]</A></SUP> People Can Fly later returned to being an independent studio and their own name in 2015, but continued to help Epic with <I>Fortnite</I><SPAN class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</SPAN>s development.<SUP id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-23">[22]</A></SUP></P>
<P>During <I>Fortnite</I><SPAN class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</SPAN>s development, Epic had seen the game industry shifting to <A href="/wiki/Software_as_a_service" title="Software as a service">games as a service model</A>. To help with this transition, the company brought in <A href="/wiki/Tencent" title="Tencent">Tencent</A> who had several games operating under this model. As part of this agreement, Tencent bought a significant share of ownership in Epic Games through stock acquisition around June 2012.<SUP id="cite_ref-pcgamesn_jun2017_24-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-pcgamesn_jun2017-24">[23]</A></SUP> The shifting of Epic's approach through Tencent led to the departure of some high-level staff later that year, including Bleszinski.<SUP id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-25">[24]</A></SUP> <I>Fortnite</I> was seen as the spearhead for Epic's games-as-a-service model as they collaborated with Tencent. This caused some road bumps in the development of <I>Fortnite</I>, according to Mustard.<SUP id="cite_ref-pcgamesn_jun2017_24-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-pcgamesn_jun2017-24">[23]</A></SUP> <I>Fortnite</I><SPAN class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</SPAN>s development was also slowed as it was used as the testing ground for the new features of the Unreal 4 engine.<SUP id="cite_ref-pcgamesn_jun2017_24-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-pcgamesn_jun2017-24">[23]</A></SUP></P>
<P>By November 2013, Epic confirmed that <I>Fortnite</I> would not release that year, nor offered a target released date, though affirmed the game was still in development by several of its studios.<SUP id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-26">[25]</A></SUP> <I>Fortnite</I> was a feature in the May 2014 issue of <I><A href="/wiki/Game_Informer" title="Game Informer">Game Informer</A></I>, revealing that the title would be released as a <A href="/wiki/Free-to-play" title="Free-to-play">free-to-play</A> game.<SUP id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-27">[26]</A></SUP></P>
<P>By 2014, <I>Fortnite</I> was at a "pretty functional prototype" with most of the Unreal 4 engine elements smoothed out, according to Mustard.<SUP id="cite_ref-pcgamesn_jun2017_24-3" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-pcgamesn_jun2017-24">[23]</A></SUP> Epic anticipated it would still take about three more years to complete, not only in polishing and balancing the game, but setting in place the necessary backend elements for the games-as-a-service model.<SUP id="cite_ref-pcgamesn_jun2017_24-4" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-pcgamesn_jun2017-24">[23]</A></SUP> To help support development and get player feedback, Epic used a series of closed alpha test periods. The game's first closed alpha, called Online Test 1, ran from December 2 to 19, 2014, while Online Test 2 ran from March 24 to April 14, 2015.<SUP id="cite_ref-OT1_28-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OT1-28">[27]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-29">[28]</A></SUP> Epic said the first alpha was designed to help it "make sure all of our basic systems are working" and establish "a baseline for how people play in order to make Fortnite better."<SUP id="cite_ref-OT1_28-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-OT1-28">[27]</A></SUP> After being demoed at <A href="/wiki/WWDC" class="mw-redirect" title="WWDC">WWDC</A> 2015 on Mac, <I>Fortnite</I> entered closed beta testing in the fall of 2015.<SUP id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-30">[29]</A></SUP> Approximately 50,000 players participated in these periods.<SUP id="cite_ref-pcgamesn_jun2017_24-5" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-pcgamesn_jun2017-24">[23]</A></SUP></P>
<P><I>Fortnite</I> was being developed alongside <I><A href="/wiki/Paragon_(video_game)" title="Paragon (video game)">Paragon</A></I>, which Epic announced on November 2015. As <I>Paragon</I> seemed to take Epic's focus, leaving little news about <I>Fortnite</I>, CEO Tim Sweeney said in March 2016 that they were still committed to <I>Fortnite</I> once <I>Paragon</I> was launched and established, given that much of the work on <I>Fortnite</I> would take time to get the right balance for gameplay. "We figure we should start with one major successful launch and do one at a time. Fortnite will be next."<SUP id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-31">[30]</A></SUP></P>
<P>By June 2017, Epic Games announced that <I>Fortnite</I> was now set for a 2018 release across Windows, macOS, and the <A href="/wiki/PlayStation_4" title="PlayStation 4">PlayStation 4</A> and <A href="/wiki/Xbox_One" title="Xbox One">Xbox One</A> consoles. Leading up to this free-to-play release, the game was offered as a paid <A href="/wiki/Early_access" title="Early access">early access</A> period starting on July 25, 2017 for all platforms; players who pre-ordered Founder's Packs were granted access to the game on July 21.<SUP id="cite_ref-earlyaccess_32-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-earlyaccess-32">[31]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-33">[32]</A></SUP> The lengthy period since the game's alpha phases was ascribed to developing <I>Fortnite</I> as a games-as-a-service model, according to creative lead Donald Mustard. While the game had been in a playable state for the two years before this, Epic wanted to be able to develop ongoing content to players to keep them interested in the title, such as planning timed events with unique rewards, following in the approach used by games like <I><A href="/wiki/League_of_Legends" title="League of Legends">League of Legends</A></I> and <I><A href="/wiki/Warframe" title="Warframe">Warframe</A></I>.<SUP id="cite_ref-earlyaccess_32-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-earlyaccess-32">[31]</A></SUP> Since the game had already been announced earlier in 2014 through <I>Game Informer</I>, Epic opted not to use their <A href="/wiki/Electronic_Entertainment_Expo" title="Electronic Entertainment Expo">Electronic Entertainment Expo</A> time or space in June 2017 to re-announce the game, fearing that coverage of it would be lost in the deluge of other gaming news coming out of the event. Instead, the Epic marketing team worked with <A href="/wiki/Twitch.tv" title="Twitch.tv">Twitch</A> and other game streamers to provide them early copies of the game to play and promote on their channels in the weeks leading up to their target release date of July 25, 2017. However, a few weeks before this date, Epic recognized that the game was still not ready for release; it was playable but not content complete. Rather than prolonging it further, Epic decided to release the game into paid early access on July 25, 2017, which would also allow them to get active feedback on the game as they progressed in development.<SUP id="cite_ref-glixed_gdc2018_34-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-glixed_gdc2018-34">[33]</A></SUP> At the time of the start of early access, <A href="/wiki/Gearbox_Software" title="Gearbox Software">Gearbox Software</A> helped distribute the game on physical media.<SUP id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-35">[34]</A></SUP></P>
<P>With the popularity of <I><A href="/wiki/Fortnite_Battle_Royale" title="Fortnite Battle Royale">Fortnite Battle Royale</A></I>, which was first released in early access around September 2017 and gained considerable attention by early 2018, Epic split off a separate development team to focus on improvements for this mode.<SUP id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-36">[35]</A></SUP> Epic said that their attention to <I>Fortnite</I> was causing some of their other games to see lower player populations, leading them to reduce development efforts on these games, particularly <I>Paragon</I>.<SUP id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-37">[36]</A></SUP> By the end of January 2018, Epic announced it was shutting down <I>Paragon</I> by April of that year, providing refunds to all players.<SUP id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-38">[37]</A></SUP> Players on a <I>Fortnite</I>-dedicated <A href="/wiki/Reddit" title="Reddit">Reddit</A> forum had expressed concerns that a similar fate could befall the <I>Save the World</I> mode of <I>Fortnite</I>, as externally, the <I>Save the World</I> mode has not received the same attention in providing updates and improvements compared to the <I>Battle Royale</I> mode since that mode's release.<SUP id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-39">[38]</A></SUP> Epic's Ed Zobrist said that as of March 2018 that the retention rates for "Save the World" have been high, and have grown since the release of <I>Fortnite Battle Royale</I>,<SUP id="cite_ref-glixed_gdc2018_34-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-glixed_gdc2018-34">[33]</A></SUP> and the company has since improved communications with the player base, such as providing development road maps and known bug lists.<SUP id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-40">[39]</A></SUP></P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Art_and_design">Art and design</SPAN></H3>
<P>In their initial prototypes of the game, Epic had used creepier and darker designs for the husks and other enemies. Bleszinski said that they found this to create an "exhaustive environment" that was too grim, and designed to take the design in a more cartoonish approach, while still remaining creepy, so that players would enjoy spending time in the game's world, without competing with games like <I><A href="/wiki/DayZ_(video_game)" title="DayZ (video game)">DayZ</A></I>.<SUP id="cite_ref-eurgamer_Sept2012_19-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-eurgamer_Sept2012-19">[18]</A></SUP> They used works from <A href="/wiki/Pixar" title="Pixar">Pixar</A>, <A href="/wiki/Tim_Burton" title="Tim Burton">Tim Burton</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Looney_Tunes" title="Looney Tunes">Looney Tunes</A> as inspiration for the designs.<SUP id="cite_ref-eurgamer_Sept2012_19-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-eurgamer_Sept2012-19">[18]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-41">[40]</A></SUP></P>
<P><I>Fortnite</I> uses <A href="/wiki/Procedural_generation" title="Procedural generation">procedural generation</A> to build out the maps for each mission. The game also includes an "AI director" that monitors how players are progressing, and alters the challenges of the monsters it sends out to the players based on that progression, easing off if players are having greater difficulty in surviving.<SUP id="cite_ref-polygon_july2014_42-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-polygon_july2014-42">[41]</A></SUP> At one point, the game had a team-based <A href="/wiki/Player_versus_player" title="Player versus player">player versus player</A> mode, where each side attempted to build up a base around a central target while trying to attack the opponent's target after breaking through their base. This did not make it into the final game.<SUP id="cite_ref-polygon_july2014_42-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-polygon_july2014-42">[41]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Epic currently has <A href="/wiki/Cross-platform_play" title="Cross-platform play">cross-platform play</A> between PC and PS4 and has stated plans to allow separate <I>Fortnite</I> cross-platform support for Xbox One and personal computer users, but cross-platform play between all three platforms has not been announced. However, for a few hours during one day in September 2017, players found they could cross-play between all three platforms. Epic later corrected this, calling it a "configuration error".<SUP id="cite_ref-crossplay_43-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-crossplay-43">[42]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Reception">Reception</SPAN></H2>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Sales">Sales</SPAN></H3>
<P>On July 26, 2017, it was announced that <I>Fortnite</I> had sold over 500,000 digital pre-order copies.<SUP id="cite_ref-ign_2-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-ign-2">[1]</A></SUP> On August 18, 2017, Epic confirmed that <I>Fortnite</I> had surpassed over a million players.<SUP id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-44">[43]</A></SUP></P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Accolades">Accolades</SPAN></H3>
<P><I><A href="/wiki/Eurogamer" title="Eurogamer">Eurogamer</A></I> ranked the game 32nd on their list of the "Top 50 Games of 2017".<SUP id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-45">[44]</A></SUP> It was also nominated for "Best Co-op Game" in <I><A href="/wiki/PC_Gamer" title="PC Gamer">PC Gamer</A></I><SPAN class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</SPAN>s 2017 Game of the Year Awards,<SUP id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-46">[45]</A></SUP> and for "Best Spectator Game" in <A href="/wiki/IGN" title="IGN">IGN</A>'s Best of 2017 Awards.<SUP id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-47">[46]</A></SUP></P>

<P><B>Texas Flip N Move</B> is a show featured on <A href="/wiki/DIY_Network" title="DIY Network">DIY Network</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-1">[1]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-Zap2it_2-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Zap2it-2">[2]</A></SUP></P>

<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Premise">Premise</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Texas_Flip_N_Move&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: Premise">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<P>The show features professional home renovators who purchase older houses to <A href="/wiki/Property_flipping" class="mw-redirect" title="Property flipping">flip</A> for profit.</P>
<P>However, unlike <A href="/wiki/Property_Brothers" title="Property Brothers">Property Brothers</A> or other similar shows, the show features a twist: at the auction, only the <I><B>houses</B></I> are sold (not the underlying land). The bidders can only view the home from the outside and must also factor in costs of moving the house from the original lot to the renovation site (another facility where the houses are renovated and later sold at auction to purchasers wanting houses to move to existing property).</P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Cast">Cast</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Texas_Flip_N_Move&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: Cast">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<UL>
<LI>Donna Snow Landers and Toni Snow Barksdale ("The Snow Sisters") (Season 1-present)</LI>
<LI>Randy Martin ("The Lone Wolf") (Season 1-present)</LI>
<LI><A href="/w/index.php?title=Myers_Jackson&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Myers Jackson (page does not exist)">Myers Jackson</A> (the selling <A href="/wiki/Auctioneer" class="mw-redirect" title="Auctioneer">auctioneer</A>) (Season 1-present)</LI>
<LI>Casey Hester and Catrina Kidd (Seasons 4-present)</LI>
</UL>
<DL>
<DD>From Season 1 to Season 3, Casey was Cody's cousin and moved houses for the Young Guns. From Season 3 he moves and flips house with the Young Guns at season 3 and with Catrina from Season 4. Casey and Catrina are not married to each other.</DD>
</DL>
<UL>
<LI>"Gary's Girls" (Season 4-present)</LI>
</UL>
<DL>
<DD>Gary Snow is the brother of Donna and Toni; his four daughters (Donna and Toni's nieces) were featured in a Season 3 episode where they and the Snow Sisters each renovated a shipping contain</DD>
</DL>
<UL>
<LI>Paige and Raf. (Seasons 6-present)</LI>
<LI>Gary and Jerry (Seasons 7-present)</LI>
<LI>Cody Biffel (Foreman)</LI>
<LI>Cody and Suzi Slay ("The Young Guns") (Seasons 1-3)</LI>
<LI>H.D. "Daddy" Snow (occasional appearances)</LI>
</UL>
<DL>
<DD>Daddy Snow is the father of Donna, Gary, and Toni, and the grandfather of Gary's four daughters. In his 80's, he is still active in the house-moving business. He inherited a company created by his father C.A. Snow.</DD>
</DL>

<H1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Economy of the Ming dynasty</H1>			<DIV id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
				<DIV id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</DIV>				<DIV id="contentSub"></DIV>
								<DIV id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">

				<DIV id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><DIV class="mw-parser-output"><TABLE class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">

<DIV class="thumb tright">
<DIV class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><A href="/wiki/File:Ming_Empire_cca_1580_(en).svg" class="image"><IMG alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Ming_Empire_cca_1580_%28en%29.svg/220px-Ming_Empire_cca_1580_%28en%29.svg.png" width="220" height="224" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Ming_Empire_cca_1580_%28en%29.svg/330px-Ming_Empire_cca_1580_%28en%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Ming_Empire_cca_1580_%28en%29.svg/440px-Ming_Empire_cca_1580_%28en%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="2304" data-file-height="2344" /></A>
<DIV class="thumbcaption">
<DIV class="magnify"><A href="/wiki/File:Ming_Empire_cca_1580_(en).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></A></DIV>
The Ming Empire around 1580</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>The <B>economy of the <A href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</A></B> (1368–1644) of <A href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</A> was the largest in the world during that period. It is regarded as one of China's three <A href="/wiki/Golden_Age_(metaphor)" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Age (metaphor)">golden ages</A> (the other two being the <A href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han</A> and <A href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song</A> periods). The period was marked by the increasing political influence of the <A href="/wiki/Merchant" title="Merchant">merchants</A>, the gradual weakening of <A href="/wiki/Emperor_of_China" title="Emperor of China">imperial rule</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Technology" title="Technology">technological</A> advances.</P>
<P></P>

<P></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Currency">Currency</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: Currency">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<DIV role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <A href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty_coinage" title="Ming dynasty coinage">Ming dynasty coinage</A></DIV>
<P>The early <A href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</A> attempted to use <A href="/wiki/Fiat_currency" class="mw-redirect" title="Fiat currency">paper currency</A>, with outflows of <A href="/wiki/Bullion" title="Bullion">bullion</A> limited by its <A href="/wiki/Haijin" title="Haijin">ban on private foreign commerce</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-1">[1]</A></SUP> Like <A href="/wiki/History_of_Chinese_currency" title="History of Chinese currency">its forebears</A>, the currency experienced massive <A href="/wiki/Counterfeit" title="Counterfeit">counterfeiting</A> and <A href="/wiki/Hyperinflation" title="Hyperinflation">hyperinflation</A>. (In 1425, Ming notes were trading at about 0.014% of its original value under the Hongwu Emperor.)<SUP id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-2">[2]</A></SUP> The notes remained in circulation as late as 1573 but their printing was ended in 1450. <A href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty_coinage" title="Ming dynasty coinage">Minor coins</A> were minted in base metals, but trade mostly occurred using <A href="/wiki/Sycee" title="Sycee">silver ingots</A>. As their purity and exact weight varied, they were treated as <A href="/wiki/Bullion" title="Bullion">bullion</A> and measured in <A href="/wiki/Tael" title="Tael">tael</A>. These privately made "<A href="/wiki/Sycee" title="Sycee">sycee</A>" first came into use in <A href="/wiki/Guangdong" title="Guangdong">Guangdong</A>, spreading to the <A href="/wiki/Yangtze_Delta" class="mw-redirect" title="Yangtze Delta">lower Yangtze</A> sometime before 1423, the year it became acceptable for payment of tax obligations. In the mid-15th century, the paucity of circulating silver caused a monetary contraction and extensive reversion to <A href="/wiki/Barter" title="Barter">barter</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-3">[3]</A></SUP> The problem was met through smuggled, then legal, importation of <A href="/wiki/Ashikaga_shogunate" title="Ashikaga shogunate">Japanese</A> silver (mostly through the <A href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</A> and <A href="/wiki/Dutch_Republic" title="Dutch Republic">Dutch</A>) and <A href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish</A> silver from <A href="/wiki/Potos%C3%AD" title="Potosí">Potosí</A> carried on the <A href="/wiki/Manila_galleons" class="mw-redirect" title="Manila galleons">Manila galleons</A>. Provincial taxes were required to be paid in silver in 1465; the salt tax, in 1475; and <A href="/wiki/Corv%C3%A9e" title="Corvée">corvée</A> exemptions, in 1485. By the late Ming, the amount of silver being used was extraordinary: at a time when <A href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">English</A> traders considered tens of thousands of pounds an exceptional fortune, the Zheng clan of merchants regularly engaged in transactions valued at millions of <A href="/wiki/Tael" title="Tael">taels</A>. However, a second silver contraction occurred in the mid-17th century when <SPAN class="nowrap"><A href="/wiki/Philip_IV_of_Spain" title="Philip IV of Spain">King Philip IV</A></SPAN> began enforcing laws limiting direct trade between <A href="/wiki/Spanish_South_America" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish South America">Spanish South America</A> and China at about the same time the new <A href="/wiki/Tokugawa_shogunate" title="Tokugawa shogunate">Tokugawa shogunate</A> in Japan restricted most of its foreign exports, cutting off Dutch and Portuguese access to its silver. The dramatic spike in silver's value in China made payment of taxes nearly impossible for most provinces.<SUP id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-4">[4]</A></SUP> <I>In extremis</I>, the government even resumed use of paper currency amid <A href="/wiki/Li_Zicheng" title="Li Zicheng">Li Zicheng</A>'s rebellion.</P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Manufactures">Manufactures</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: Manufactures">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Privatization">Privatization</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=3" title="Edit section: Privatization">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>Another key feature of the Ming manufacturing industry was <A href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">privatization</A>. Unlike the Song, in which <A href="/wiki/Government-owned_corporation" class="mw-redirect" title="Government-owned corporation">state-owned enterprises</A> played a large role, the Ming reverted to the old laissez faire policies of the Han by privatizing the salt and tea industries. By the middle of the Ming dynasty, powerful groups of wealthy merchants had replaced the state as the dominant movers behind Chinese industry.</P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Emergence_of_wage_labor">Emergence of wage labor</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=4" title="Edit section: Emergence of wage labor">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>The Ming government abolished the mandatory forced labor by peasants used in early dynasties and replaced it with wage labor. A new class of wage laborers sprung up where none had existed before. In Jingde alone, it was reported that there were no less than 300 pottery factories, all operated by wage laborers.<SUP id="cite_ref-Bo&Zheng_5-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Bo&Zheng-5">[5]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Early_encouragement_of_agriculture_under_Hongwu">Early encouragement of agriculture under Hongwu</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=5" title="Edit section: Early encouragement of agriculture under Hongwu">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<P>In order to recover from rule of the Mongols and the wars that followed them, the <A href="/wiki/Hongwu_Emperor" title="Hongwu Emperor">Hongwu Emperor</A> enacted pro-agricultural policies. The state invested extensively in agricultural canals, reduced taxes on agriculture to 1/30 of the output, and later to 1.5% of agricultural output. Ming farmers also introduced many innovations such as water-powered plows, and new agricultural methods such as crop rotation. This led to a massive agricultural surplus that became the basis of a market economy.<SUP id="cite_ref-Bo&Zheng_5-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Bo&Zheng-5">[5]</A></SUP></P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Emergence_of_commercial_plantations">Emergence of commercial plantations</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=6" title="Edit section: Emergence of commercial plantations">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>The Ming saw the rise of commercial plantations who produced crops suitable to their regions. Tea, fruits, paint and other goods were produced on a massive scale by these agricultural plantations. Regional patterns of production established during this period continued into the Qing dynasty.<SUP id="cite_ref-Bo&Zheng_5-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Bo&Zheng-5">[5]</A></SUP> The <A href="/wiki/Columbian_exchange" class="mw-redirect" title="Columbian exchange">Columbian exchange</A> brought crops such as <A href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">corn</A> with these foreign crops. During the Ming, specialized areas also popped up planting large numbers of cash crops that could be sold at markets. Large numbers of peasants abandoned the land to become artisans. The population of the Ming boomed; estimates for the population of the Ming range from 160 to 200 million.</P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Rural_markets_during_the_Ming">Rural markets during the Ming</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=7" title="Edit section: Rural markets during the Ming">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>Ming agriculture was much changed from the earlier areas; firstly, gigantic areas, devoting and specializing in cash crops, sprung up to demand from the new market economy. Secondly, agricultural tools and carts, some water-powered, help to create a gigantic agricultural surplus which formed the basis of the rural economy. Besides rice, other crops were grown on a large scale.<SUP id="cite_ref-Bo&Zheng_5-3" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Bo&Zheng-5">[5]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Although images of autarkic farmers who had no connection to the rest of China may have some merit for the earlier Han and T'ang dynasties, this was certainly not the case for the Ming dynasty. During the Ming dynasty, the increase in population and the decrease in quality land made it necessary that farmers make a living off cash crops. Many of these markets appeared in the rural countryside, where goods were exchanged and bartered.<SUP id="cite_ref-Twitchett_6-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Twitchett-6">[6]</A></SUP></P>
<P>A second type of market that developed in China was the urban-rural type, in which rural goods were sold to urban dwellers. This was particular the case when landlords decided to reside in the cities, and use income coming from rural land holding to facilitate exchange in the cities. Another way this type of market was used was professional merchants who bought rural goods in large quantities.<SUP id="cite_ref-Twitchett_6-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Twitchett-6">[6]</A></SUP></P>
<P>The third type of market was the "national market" which was developed during the Song dynasty but particularly enhanced during the Ming. This market involved not only the exchange described above, but also products produced directly for the market. Unlike earlier dynasties, many Ming peasants were no longer producing only products they needed; many of them produced products for the market, which then they sold at a profit.<SUP id="cite_ref-Twitchett_6-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-Twitchett-6">[6]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Trade_and_investment">Trade and investment</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=8" title="Edit section: Trade and investment">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<DIV role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <A href="/wiki/Haijin" title="Haijin">Haijin</A></DIV>
<P>In the early Ming, after the devastation of the war which expelled the Mongols, the <A href="/wiki/Hongwu_Emperor" title="Hongwu Emperor">Hongwu Emperor</A> imposed <A href="/wiki/Haijin" title="Haijin">severe restrictions on trade</A> (the "<I>haijin</I>"). Believing that agriculture was the basis of the economy, Hongwu favored that industry over all else, including that of merchants. After his death, most of his policies were reversed by his successors. By the late Ming, the state was losing power to the very merchants which Hongwu had wanted to restrict.</P>
<P>The Ming dynasty also engaged in a thriving trade with both Europe and Japan. The amount of silver flowing into the Ming dynasty was estimated by Joseph Needham at 300 million taels, which is equivalent to more than 190 billion dollars in today's money. In addition to silver, the Ming also imported many European firearms, in order to ensure the modernness of their weapons.</P>
<P>Trade and commerce thrived in this liberalized economy, and was aided by the construction of <A href="/wiki/Canal" title="Canal">canals</A>, <A href="/wiki/Road" title="Road">roads</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Bridge" title="Bridge">bridges</A> by the Ming government. The Ming saw the rise of several merchant clans such as the Huai and Jin clans, who disposed of large amounts of wealth. The <A href="/wiki/Gentry" title="Gentry">gentry</A> and merchant classes started to fuse, and the merchants gained power at the expense of the state. Some merchants were reputed to have a treasure of 30 million taels.</P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Taxation">Taxation</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=9" title="Edit section: Taxation">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>Ming taxation was light. Taxes on agriculture were only 1/30 of agricultural produce, and were later reduced to 1/50 of produce. Taxes on commerce amounted to 1/30 of commerce also, but was later reduced to 1.5%. These low taxes spurred trade, but severely weakened the state. Salt, as in earlier dynasties, was <A href="/wiki/Salt_in_Chinese_History#Complication_and_frustration_in_the_Ming_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Salt in Chinese History">an important source of state revenue</A>, but required constant and competent management. With the coming of the <A href="/wiki/Little_Ice_Age" title="Little Ice Age">Little Ice Age</A> in the 17th century, the state's low revenues and its inability to raise taxes caused massive deficits, and large numbers of Ming troops defected or rebelled because they had not been paid.<SUP id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-7">[7]</A></SUP></P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Weakening_of_the_state">Weakening of the state</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=10" title="Edit section: Weakening of the state">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>During the Ming, the controls imposed on the economy were gradually relaxed. <A href="/wiki/Government_monopoly" class="mw-redirect" title="Government monopoly">State monopolies</A> on <A href="/wiki/Salt" title="Salt">salt</A> and iron ended as these and other industries were privatized. Taxes were reduced from the high levels under the Mongol <A href="/wiki/Yuan_dynasty" title="Yuan dynasty">Yuan</A>, and the Ming had one of the lowest tax rates (per person) in the world. The entire foreign trade, which was estimated at up to 300 million taels, provided the Ming with a tax of only about 40,000 taels a year. When the <A href="/wiki/Wanli_Emperor" title="Wanli Emperor">Wanli Emperor</A> sought to increase the salt tax, his measures were opposed by violence and the eunuchs he sent to collect the tax were beheaded by local officials.</P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Sprouts_of_capitalism">Sprouts of capitalism</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Economy_of_the_Ming_dynasty&action=edit&section=11" title="Edit section: Sprouts of capitalism">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>Investment and capital moved off the land and were poured into ventures. Continuing the trend from the Song, Ming investors poured large amounts of capital into ventures and reaped high profits. Many Chinese scholars believe the Ming was the dynasty in which the "<A href="/wiki/Sprouts_of_capitalism" title="Sprouts of capitalism">sprouts of capitalism</A>" emerged in China, only to be suppressed by the Qing Dynastry. This theory was widely promoted by Communist scholars during the Maoist period, and suffers from that period's general condemnation of the Manchu Qing, who were accused of mis-managing the Chinese state in the face of foreign encroachment.</P>
